title: Deuce of Spades Backpacking Trowel Handle

description.text:
We love the Deuce of Spades backpacking trowel. It weighs a mere 0.7oz, packs easily, and digs better and more quickly than our other trowels. The aluminum is so thin it chops thru small to pencil-sized roots. But that same thin profile cuts into your hand a little on the back end too.

This thing is a vestigal handle intended to make the digging experience a little more comfortable. Note there are 2 versions: rigid-filament and flex-filament. I prefer the rigid version, but YMMV.

Rigid (purple or clear in photo): Printed at 0.35u in PETG (clear) or enhanced PLA (purple) it seems pretty sturdy and protects my hand well. Both were printed with the curved surface/palm flange down and the slot facing straight up, support enabled, 100% infill.

Flex (yellow-green in photo): Printed at 0.35u in TPU. I had to remove the palm flange because I couldn't get support to separate from the model. Instead I made the build-plate interface flat so no support would be needed. I trimmed the corners off with kitchen shears and rounded/smoothed the edges post-printing to make it comfortable to hold. Print with the flat, closed edge down and the slot straight up.

Net weight of any one of these handles and the trowel together is still less than 1 oz.

Note: I backed the Deuce of Spades Kickstarter some years ago and it's lightened my pack ever since. But I have no affiliation besides the Kickstarter pledge.

title: Alternative gun stock for HTC Vive

description.text:
This is a different kind of setup than most. I call it "The Homewrecker". The trigger hand controller is clamped in place while the front controller is free and just used to support the barrel.

Advantages over a bottom mount type stock: faster access to your grenades, comms, and reloading since you never fumble around trying to stick your controllers back into the cups.

Disadvantages: the right controller is locked in position, so when you throw a grenade, you are swinging the entire stock. This obviously can be hazardous to your surroundings, TV screens, drinks, pets, friends, spouse, etc. (hence the name). You definitely need some space if you are swinging this around - I recommend lobbing grenades underhand only.

The "barrel" length is just long enough to use the Volk G3 with a fore-grip in Onward. You could shorten the front section by about 5 cm to make it more compact (less hazardous), but it would limit your weapon choices somewhat.

author: Thirteen

title: Lathe 3-Jaw Chuck Spacer for Short Stock - Spider

description.text:
This is to space out short stock for turning or facing operations in a 3-jaw lathe chuck. It flexes over the jaws to take up 3/4" of space. There is a center hole which could be threaded for a stud/bolt to further space stock outward if needed and 3 holes for set screws for finer adjustment if needed for leveling (Magnets could be pressed into these to hold it to the body of the chuck).
The center of this naturally takes up space so the minimum grip diameter possible is about 5/8" diameter. This is sized to fit jaws which are 3/4" wide and designed to flex and grip lightly. On a chuck with narrower jaws (I have tried it on a 5" chuck that had about 5/8" wide jaws) this is loose but does not rattle excessively at speed with a part against it.
This shape is rather bizarre when viewed out of context but it works quite well on a 6" 3-jaw Chuck.

In my case:
1.) Printed it flat with ABS through a .5-mm tip, 25% infill, 3 boundary layers, and a skirt of 4 layers.
2.) Let it cool and popped it off the Kapton tape covered heated bed
3.) Cleaned off the skirt and rough edges.
4.) It slips right on or off for whenever it is needed.

description.text: This is a 3d printed model derived from MOLA data of Gale Crater where the newest Mars rover Curiousity touched down.  Called a "geological candy shop" it has a mountain in the center.

Created by taking the MOLA image of Gale crater (http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Topographic_Map_of_Gale_Crater.jpg/200px-Topographic_Map_of_Gale_Crater.jpg) and converting the colors to grayscale to indicate depth. The image was then used to create a heightfield from bitmap in Rhino3D, slightly smoothed (there are always artifacts from color replacement), converted to a mesh, the edges extended and sliced off to form a shallow box which was then merged with the surface heightfield mesh. Saved as an stl file, printed at 0.27 layer thickness with 1 shell, 5% infill, no raft or support. Some warping seems inevitable on my printer, but not too bad. At these settings took about 1.5 hours to print. Will pair very nicely with ThePlanetMike's rover (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27908). Sorry about the quality of the pic - printing in silver/gray ABS seems to enhance blobs and edges, particularly in photographs. Will try printing in natural and black ABS which tend to photograph better (and melt a bit more easily, reducing said edges and blobs). UPDATE: I just uploaded a much smaller stl file - it has been smoothed (laplacian smooth) with Meshlab. Slightly less detail but much more manageable size. I'll try printing this afternoon.

description.text:
Update

I've added a second file that includes a loop to hang the Pi Divider on a hook for storage. You'll probably only want one loop, so print one of each.

Note that the original update placed the loop on the inside of the tool. This is still usable but is not ideal. The files have now been updated so that when the tool is in the open position, the loop is on the outside.

Original Summary

What Is It?
This is a tool for correctly sizing a glass collar to roll up a cane mat in glassblowing. It operates like scissors, and the lengths are sized so that the larger opening is always pi times larger than the smaller opening. This means that when you lay out your cane and open the long, straight side to the width of the cane, the smaller curved ends are the perfect collar diameter. The plastic will melt if it comes near the hot glass of course, so use this tool to set the right width on your metal calipers once you've laid out your cane.

Chances are if you're searching for a pi divider, you already knew all that. If you didn't, search for videos of the 'reticello' process and you'll see why this is useful.

Assembly
You'll need a short screw and matching nut to join the two pieces together. I like to use an additional nut to lock the first in place. Tighten the first nut so that the Pi Divider has some resistance to movement but can still open and close. Then, holding the first nut, tighten a second down hard against the first (careful not to overtighten and squeeze the plastic parts!). This locks the first nut in place and leaves you with a moveable Pi Divider that won't easily lose its position.

Modify it!
Note that you can size this yourself using Fusion 360 and the .f3d file. See below section for important notes.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200um

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You'll need to print two of them to assemble the Pi Divider. If your print bed is smooth, print both parts with the same orientation (see picture of parts on the Prusa print bed). That way the smooth surfaces will be together after assembly.

If the ends start to peel up, use a 5mm raft (brim).

The .f3d file includes two user parameters, Length and HoleD. The diameter of the hole can be changed to suit whatever fastener you want to use. The overall length can also be changed based on what you need, and everything else (except for the hole diameter) will scale accordingly.

HOWEVER there's a quirk in one of the sketch arcs that causes it to invert if the Length parameter is changed by too large an increment. So if you want to increase/decrease the overall length, make multiple changes in 1-inch (or even 0.5 inch) increments to avoid the arc problem. If you have any problems, leave a comment and I'll respond.

Happy printing!

title: Extra Bracket Parts for ThermalTake Core X9 case (140mm fan)

description.text:
These are some parts I designed to make my Core X9 custom case build work out how I wanted it. Included is a 3x 3.5" HDD Bracket, 3x 2.5" SSD Bracket and 120-140mm Pump mount adaptor all designed around running 3x 140mm fans in the bottom left side of the case.

These designs should fit on any 140mm fan and may well be useful for applications outside of my original use case.

Also included is a small adapter to install a 2nd 140mm fan on the right side of the case, near the PSU.

I hope that these are of some use to Core X9 owners!

Comments and suggestions welcome :D

*The 2 parts of the HDD Bracket should be printed face down with no support.

*The SSD Bracket should be printed as is with support.

*The pump bracket adaptor should be printed upside down with support.

*The fan bracket should be printed on edge with no support.

The HDD/SSD/Pump brackets in my shots were printed with Fillaprint Permium White PLA and the fan bracket was printed with a sample of UV reactive white>blue PLA.

All prints sliced in Simplify 3d with default Wanhao settings and Printed on my Wanhao i3 Plus.

Small and space saving

What to do with empty spools? I asked myself, than I saw some similar shelves, but none of them was "that" type. So I did this. Hope it will be useful.

Assembly

You need four main parts for each level. I glued it to the spool with cyanoacrylate. There are bearings between spools. They are designed to use 6mm plastic BB gun balls, so it is very easy to get them. Or you can use any other 6mm balls.

I recommend to put a pipe through whole organizer and fix it on the table. Locks are not much reliable and it can happen that you will pick dozens of your things from the ground. Just be carefull.

title: Bioshock-Inspired Nexus 5X Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a remix of my Nexus 5X case (over here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2424774), adding a Bioshock-inspired logo onto the back. The logo itself I don't remember seeing in the game, so I suspect its a fan-inspired thing, but its all over the web, so its hard to tell what its origin is.

This is, admittedly, an extremely challenging print to get done. As is, the case won't fit over a phone if its printed with PLA. Its possible if you snipped off the upper edges above the volume and power buttons, you might get enough flex to get it to fit, but... who knows. I haven't tried.

To get it to print properly, as designed, you need a dual-material printer that can handle flex filament. That's not super-common because most multi-material printers are Bowden-based and struggle with flex.

There's three parts -- the case, with an opening for the logo, and the black and white (or whatever colors you choose) parts of the logo. Load all three into your slicer as a single multi-material object, and you should be able to adjust the extruder and settings for each one.

For the printed version in the photo, I used Slic3r Prusa Edition. The logo was printed in black and white TPU filament, with normal settings. The case was printed using the black extruder, with the infill set to print with the white extruder. The case was printed with two top layers, and zero bottom layers, with a 30% hex infill. The end result is the bottom having the hex pattern in white, and the sides being black, even though its a single part. You could, of course, print it however you wanted.

The bridging over the openings for the USB port and the buttons is particularly difficult for printers to bridge in flex. If your printer can't handle it, you can just snip the mess off after -- there's enough rigidity in the upper lip to hold the case securely just with the other edges. (Which is part of why its likely you won't be able to get it on with a PLA print.)

And if you're thinking "hey, that marble effect is really cool" -- its just a bit of luck. The black was oozing a bit when laying down the first couple layers, and the strings got embedded in the white like that.

print_settings.Notes:: Infill pattern to taste... I used 15% triangles for the sides and 20% grid for the top for the print speed, but I think I'd do honeycomb all around for the next one I print.

description.text: Simple customizable can dispenser to put in your fridge. The included STLs are for US 355 mL (12 fl oz) cans in a dispenser 341mm deep and 160mm high. Want something else? Go grab OpenSCAD (I recommend a development snapshot, it has a customizer UI you can turn on in the prefs) or see if Thingiverse's customizer is working today. Height is adjusted manually so you can have dispensers for different sized cans next to each other and still have a flat top.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This one's a bit complicated... if your print bed is large enough (or fridge small enough, I suppose) you can use the full side and top pieces. Otherwise, you'll need the half side and tops.

For the side pieces, print with zero top and bottom layers and 15% infill. The STLs give you the right side; mirror and print again for the left.

For the top piece, if you're using Slic3r double click on the object, click load modifier, and select the matching modifier STL. Then, highlight the modifier in the list and click the + under object settings. Select layers -> bottom solid layers and set it to zero. Do the same for layers -> top solid layers. When you slice, this'll give you a top piece that is solid where you glue it to the sides but mesh in the center for airflow.

Infill pattern to taste... I used 15% triangles for the sides and 20% grid for the top for the print speed, but I think I'd do honeycomb all around for the next one I print.

The pieces need to be glued together. I used standard superglue.

If you're using the half side pieces, glue them together in the middle. Then, glue the bottom supports on to the bottom. Once that's dried, glue the top on and you're done.

I designed the gap as 1.75mm since my printer is producing holes and gaps a little narrower. Thus, I got nice snag fit with 1.75mm filaments. Not all printers are the same. Therefore, you might need to print a sample and see if a size change is needed or not.
For 2.85mm diameter filament, I have no chance to test the design since I ve got no filament in that size in hand.

description.text:
Hipster's Base Ten Blocks are an awesome idea, and I just wanted a little more detail, so that from all sides (and the bottom) each group of blocks looked a little more like individual blocks.

In the end it was easier to start over from scratch than modify Hipster's files, because this is geometrically pretty straightforward. But it was Hipster's original idea, and I've just copied it with a little bit different shape.

Note: the 0100 (10 x 10 or 100-blocks) models come in two flavors: regular and with holes. The "holes" one has natural holes between the individual blocks, because the blocks have beveled edges. It might make the nature of the "100 blocks" block more obvious to children (i.e., it looks more like 100 blocks instead of one blobby block), but it also takes much longer to print.

I created this in Meshmixer, and the .mix files are included.

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.12

Infill:

50%

Notes:

These take longer than Hipster's blocks to print because there is more detail and fewer long, straight lines.

You need good bed adhesion because the first few layers will be a matrix of small squares that must be built up until they connect. In my case, a sheet of PEI on my printer bed (now finally flat after I replaced the glass!) did just fine, with appropriate leveling. YMMV.

You can probably print these pretty fast, especially after the first few layers connect. I printed at 80 mm/s, but probably could have done 100 mm/s You can also do thinner walls and less infill than I did, but I wanted mine to be durable enough to get dropped on the floor without (hopefully) breaking.

I used Meshmixer. Made a cube, then wrapped other cubes around it and used those to shave off the corners so the result was beveled.

For multi-block models I lined up multiple cubes and made solids from them.

Printed in silver PLA at Cura's "75% size" (so each cube is 0.75 cm x 0.75 cm x 0.75 cm) Detail of the 0100_holes.stl model (at 75% x 75% x 75% dimensions). It took about 8 hours to print at 0.12 mm layer height and 30% (I think) quarter cubic infill, with 3 or 4 shells (0.4mm nozzle) Detail to show layers.

Hal Jordan, one of the characters known as Green Lantern, is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. The character was created in 1959 by writer John Broome and artist Gil Kane, and first appeared in Showcase #22 (October 1959).

Hal Jordan is a fighter pilot, a member and occasionally leader of an intergalactic police force called the Green Lantern Corps, as well as a founding member of the Justice League, DC's flagship superhero team, alongside well-known heroes such as Batman, Superman, and Wonder Woman. He fights evil across the universe with a ring that grants him a variety of superpowers, but is usually portrayed as one of the protectors of Sector 2814, which is the sector where Earth resides. His powers derive from his power ring and Green Lantern battery, which in the hands of someone capable of overcoming great fear allows the user to channel their will power into creating all manner of fantastic constructs.

Edit 2: David Viola suggested that it might be cool to have him looking at his lantern. So here it is.

title: 40mm test squircle (for checking tool paths and print behavior)

description.text:
This is a 40mm test cube with a 15mm circle & square inside. I designed it to check tool path strategies in the slicer software and the actual print performance. Watch & hear what the print head is actually doing and stop at 30-50% print status. Then you can check the print quality and also judge the infill quality.

The screenshot shows Simplify3D with 15% Honeycomb infill and 1mm retraction lift.

Background:
I had several issues where the nozzle was hitting previously printed lines of the actual layer with 100 mm/s print speed. Namely "Grid" and "Triangles" infill but also in large flat prints where the head was traveling to a new part of the layer and also was hitting stuff. I'm aware that it is no problem with slower print speeds but then I wouldn't have had bought a delta printer which is designed to print at high speeds. And it is also a matter of tool path strategy to prevent intra-layer line crossing.

author: UncleManuel

title: inside cabinet door flip-up cookbook shelf

description.text:
I wanted something to keep a cookbook or tablet at eye level when cooking. This design folds flat against the inside of a cabinet door (I have one which swings out near my usual work area). The "hinges" connect with turkey-lacing pins cut to the right length and with a small jag at the end so they hold when forced in. The pins I get are about 10cm in length so two equal-length halves meet in the middle block for each hinge (4 pins or rods total). Any other steel rod or pin about 1.5mm in diameter will also work. Upper pins were about 6cm each and lower were about 8cm each.

If you want to try to use the lower inside groove of your cabinet door to catch the back of the tray, you might not need to print the catches.

Parts were attached using #6 screws. 3/8" or 1/2" will work since the pieces are about 1/4" thick.

Note: added a hollow back for those who might want that.

I've ordered these threaded apple chargers off of Amazon and they worked fine until a plastic plate near the part of the cable that plugs into the phone. After the plate fell off the cable soon began to bend a lot more easily until it eventually broke. I've ordered a few of them on Amazon and the plate issue seemed to be a problem every single time, for the plates tend to fall off pretty quickly. So I attempted to make a fix for it. The fix definitely works and it just snaps on the cable as if it were new. However, it is very bulky and fat and may not work on every apple product depending on the case around it. It's a lot of plastic for a paint tray, but I wanted something nice. The magnetic lid has a nice snap to it, and it saves paints fairly well.

I added a bit of silicone to seal where the faces mate, and the hinge keys will likely need a bit of sanding for a good fit.

I'll probably be making variations of this box for other uses - I like the way the hinge works.

I have a print-in-place version I started with, but it's a really tough print so that still on the drawing table unless someone wants to try it.

Dimensions are 120mm x 74.4mm x 21.5mm

description.text:
MAJ 09/03/2018 : Aesthetic improvement
A more accomplished version of the low cost dampers found on the net.
I adjusted the stiffness of the silent-block to be able to normally tension the Y-axis belt without sacrificing the geometry of the motor / return roller assembly.

you can compare the difference on the enforcement of the geometry in the picture above.

I adapted the dimensions so as not to damage the damper when tightening because of thin walls.

PET EPR is perfect for this kind of technical parts, it is indeed very resistant.

P.S. : If my English seems bad, thank you to address your complaints to Google Trad ';) And, I know, I draw like a kid of 4 years!

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You can adjust the hardness of the damper by adjusting the density of the filling.
I recommend staying at 100% for damper Y-axis because the length of the belt imposes a high tension, which may cause the sagging of the damper.

I recommend printing at a high enough temperature to optimize adhesion between the two filaments.
I printed these parts to 248 °.

Filaments used:
-Innofil PET EPR (Red)
-Recreus 95A FILAFLEX Medium Flex (Blue)

Remember to include two M600s in your gcode if you do not change your fil in manual mode.
Ex: M600 E-10 L-50 X40 Y40 Z100
The syntax of this command is detailed here:http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M600.html

title: Modular Rover Tracks - Adafruit Mini Red Round Robot Chassis

description.text:
This is a connector between the Modular Rover Tracks project and Adafruit's Mini Red Round Robot Chassis Kit.

If you already have this chassis, or are planning to buy it, this connector allows you to convert Adafruit's chassis into a all mighty tank like rover with no extra hardware!

Well, in fact you will need a couple of screws like these but you might already have them at home.

To make this connector, I just loaded the "Wheels enclosure B" part from the Modular Rover Tracks and added the required mounting points.

I did this connector per a user request in this page on hackster.io, and as an example of how you can user the Modular Rover Track with almost any chassis you have.

If you have any chassis you would like to add tracks too, you could easily do the same thing. Please let me know and I will be glad to help!

Thanks Adafruit for providing me with the documentation needed to make this! (find the details on this request here)

Assembling

To use this part, just replace the original "Wheels Enclosure B" part from the Modular Rover Tracks and you are done!

Please check Modular Rover Tracks to get more details on how to assemble that thing.

Cheers!

description.text:
I needed for many things a water pump(liquid pump), I found the peristaltic pump the best for a precision dosing, can be used also for continuous pumping, the liquid is separated by the tubing from other parts, it can be used for food and many applications safely, offers easy maintenance.
After I watched many designs, as always, I like to design my own to see how far I can make it, so feel free to suggest any useful tips!
The capacity of this pump as you can see in the video is about 160ml per minute, you can push this value a little bit it upper, but I didn't want to destroy the tubing.
The pump is easy to assemble, but I attached pictures step by step.

I started last year the project from a user interface using arduinoMega2560 with a TFT screen, the code get complicated when I added many options to control the pump(maybe I continue writing that code when I have time), but I will soon add the schematics to test this pump, with just some basic electronics( no arduino).

Parts needed:

  • 4 * M3 nuts
  • 3 * M1,85x10 screw
  • 3 * M3x3 screw
  • 4 * M3x8 screw
  • 4 * M3x11 screw
  • 3 * Bearings 5x13x4mm 695ZZ(I attached also a printable bearing if you want to try it)
  • Tubing PharMed BPT (information in the picture)

Questions also are welcome.
The files for 3D printing also here:
https://grabcad.com/library/peristaltic-pump-13

more information and updates are posted on my web pages:
http://karim.lakras.eu/

Note: I made holes for the M3 nut that are not used all of them, but they can be useful if you need to lock the parts very well. I made also deep holes for the M3 screws, so if you want to use a longer screws, they have place already.
There is attached file for the rollers if you decide to print them, make sure you make their edges smooth, so you will not cut the tubing.
Also the triangles that holds the bearings, are marked by a line as in the pictures, that sides must be in the same vertical line, that sides are locking the triangle to prevent it from turning.

Edit:
I posted a second video to show more information about the pump see bellow.

Visit my pages to see a simple schematic on how to drive the stepper and more information:

http://karim.lakras.eu/index.php?page=hobbies&lang=en&cat_hob=peristaltic

ANYCUBIC I3 MEGA

100%

author: zvezdoff

description.text:
The basic mathematics and geometry for this part came from a posting in the Rhino3d Grasshopper forum. The posting was about designing an airport control tower building that had some twisting spaces for windows along it's height.

I thought this design concept might be usable for an LED table lamp, so I used it as a basis for designing this part. This blog page explains how I have used this method before: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/from-architecture-to-3d-printing/

Most of my designs for LED lights are closed at the top, but so far I haven't figured out how to implement a closed top for this geometry. spirals2 will have a different overall shape and will have a much narrower top - but perhaps not a closed one.

This part printed in slightly less than 22.5 hours using a layer height of 0.200 mm and a print speed of 100 mm/sec.This lamp accommodates either a battery operated or wall powered "puck" LED light. This blog page has links for all the wall powered parts needed and shows how to hook everything up: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/wall-powered-led-lights/. For battery powered puck lights just go to any large home improvement store or simply Google "LED puck light".

title: Nerf Firestrike Barrel Extension
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple glue-on barrel extension for Nerf Firestrikes. Part of a larger commission project we have permission to give away publicly.

It'll only slip on one way. The test fit image is on a failed paint job with only the nerf body painted; we'll upload a pic of the finished Nerf once completed.

"Firestrike Muzzle Extension 1.stl" is V2. It has a deeper inset on the Nerf end, and fits more nicely into the overall aesthetic. IRL we'd probably cut off the barrel angle so it's not visible under the round ports, but as a prototype it didn't matter that much. Obviously it hasn't been painted yet. This was also attached with CA and kicker. Might drill out the circular ports for a bit more polish, but we'll chop off the barrel on the remaining guns to avoid the extra step.

There may be a V3 that includes a cutout for the tab just below the barrel so it sits entirely flush with the weapon, and the chamfer on the front will likely be reduced. Alternatively we may try a "combo" unit that attaches to the barrel and the light port since there are some electronics going in and the little bit of extra room can't hurt.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Using a raft may help initial plate adhesion; one of our printers is particularly slippery and the raft was necessary. Supports may be necessary depending on your printer; with them we got slightly better print quality around the barrel cutouts. 10% infill is likely more than sufficient.

Measured OD of barrel for slip-/glue-on connection. Measured ID of barrel and added some slop so it'll still function if you're looking to add this to a working Nerf. Rest was just simple cuts and some chamfers. We used Fusion 360.

title: GoPro bike mount (screwless, removable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Print as you like, but be aware, that there's quite some force involved, when driving through uneven terrain.
This mount is definitively not for offroad biking, but city tours. It is easy to remove and allows a quick installation on nearly every bike.
The mount is for a 22mm bar, but can be used for smaller or slightly bigger ones. :)

Installation

Get some rubber bands, hold your mount where you want it to be and put a rubber band around one hook. Now pull the rubber band around the bar and over the other hook.
Depending on your bike it might increase stability if you add more rubber bands, for example around the camera mount on each side (pull rubber band over GoPro, around the bar and over the GoPro again coming from the other side)

Feel free to ask me anything. If you wish I can also do other sizes or with a stronger shell. With PETG this thickness (1.2mm?) is strong enough for me, but flexible to fit nearly any bar size.

Have fun!

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Choose a material that you trust. I printed it with PETG which does not crack as easy as PLA.

Supports are easier to remove, if you choose "Zig zag" as support pattern.

description.text:
So at the first of this year I decided to set a few goals for myself, one of which was that I wanted to do something creative every day. Recently I have embarked into making knives as my day to day creative projects and I have also been documenting my creativity journey and knife making processes on instagram ( https://www.instagram.com/wpilgrim ).

I found that it was often quite difficult to set up my phone to take nice action shots of what I was working on for the day. Also I didn't want to spend a ton of time setting up the perfect shot or setting up tripods with my DSLR, I figured some kind of head mount similar to a go pro for my phone would be perfect for a lot of what I was trying to shoot.

I came to thingiverse, assuming someone had designed something like this already but I couldn't really find anything, so I made my own.

It'll look kind of goofy when you are wearing it but I just wanted a functional piece without having to mess with setup or buy some special camera.

Items you will need for this build besides the 4 printed parts are:

  • 1x 1/4-20 x 2.5" hex screw
  • 1x 1/4-20 hex nut
  • 1x homemade head strap or a repurposed one (I used this https://www.harborfreight.com/swivel-lens-headlamp-61319.html)
  • 1x 1' velcro strap
  • a bit of CA glue or superglue are fine (for gluing the cap onto the bolt)
  • optional adhesive backed padding for your forehead and or phone

description.text:
Outer diameter of the arrows on the gears shows that pitch diameter of a gear is the diameter where the gears actually mesh. While you can measure the outer diameter and get 59.85mm, this is due to tolerances and the actual pitch diameter is 60mm (as is written in the back).

The arrow direction shows that when two gears mesh, their angular velocities are opposite.

This model is small, so that all components can be printed by any printer with at least 120mm x 120mm bed size.

This print can be used as a part of power transmission lesson plans. This print demonstrates gear ratio, pitch diameter, and angular velocity.

I made this because some of my classmates struggle to understand that there's an invisible diameter in a gear where the meshing actually happens. This should make it more visible and easy to understand.
This print is a visual demonstration.

Stool made of curved plywood laths.
This stool was created at ProtoSpace, the Fablab in Utrecht.

Materials
  • 6mm plywood
  • 4 pieces threaded rod (this drawing is based on threaded rod of 8mm thick and 450mm long)
  • 8 nuts
    • Description
  • Cut out all parts from the wood with a laser cutter
  • Tighten a nut on a piece of threaded rod
  • String alternately a wooden ring and a long piece on the threaded rod
  • Tighten a nut on the other end of the threaded rod as well to secure the parts
  • Do the same for the other three corners of the stool
  • Glue the rings with the hexagonal at the bottom rings to cover the nuts
  • Glue the circular pieces of wood at the bottom of the legs
  • Glue the reinforcements of the seat on the seat
  • Place the seat on the nuts at the upper end of the stool

title: Anet E12 Heat Bed Cable Holder (Support)

description.text:
EDIT: Version 3.1 has replaced the original. This is a better design with 2 points for the zip ties which stop it from wiggling.

This is an add-on for the Anet E12 to support the heat bed cable. It removes the stress of the cable moving around from connector. This unit screws on to the where the bearing block is mounted. It should be noted that I used longer screws for this (M4x12) as it did not feel like the factory screws grabbed enough threads.

This was designed with a slot for a 4" zip tie to go through on the end and secure the cable.

I also made it go off at a 45 degree angle to keep the cable away from the Y limit switch.

NOTE: When I sliced this in Slic3r PE, it sliced it with the rib that runs the length on top of a solid layer. This delaminated on me when I flexed it. Cura printed it open and it seems better. So your mileage may vary.

title: Excalibur Proto: Sword of Promised Victory
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Makers Note: I have not printed this yet, but it is on my to do list.

To scale model of Arthur Pendragon's sword Excalibur Proto from "Fate/Prototype". What the three folders contain is as follows. The "Scabbard" folder splits the scabbard into "tubes" that can be connected together to make a hollow scabbard. The "Scabbard V.2" folder is the same as the other scabbard folder, but also slices down length-wise so you can add felt easily into the scabbard to protect the sword if you paint it. The "Sword" folder contains all the pieces for the sword, and each piece has channels for interior support like metal rods.

If you wonder what the rectangular cutouts are for, they are for magnets that you can insert to keep the scabbard and the sword together. I was unable to add the crest to the scabbard due to me not having the skill to do so. Will return to the crest, and fix later if I gain the skills.

Do you Happy?

This cat play box is intended to provide the cats with a pastime as well as to prevent them from eating their goodies at once. The cats have to push the rolls to reach the goodies - they can take it out from the top or push it through the breakthroughs of the bottom case.
Just put the goodies inside the box and let the cats try to get it.

You need to print:
1x bottom case
1x top case - print it with face down
6x roll (maybe 7) - print it upright

It should be printable without support, but depending on your configuration you may need some in the breakthroughs of the bottom case and in the deepening of the roll.

Bottom and top case have a snapin-mechanism, so you do not need to screw or glue it together.

As the roll is 2mm smaller than the inner distance of the box (a gap of 1mm on each side) it should roll smoothly. If your printer isn't configured correctly (differences between X, Y and Z lenght) you may get in trouble. I recommend to print one roll and check the size - if needed resize the lenght of the roll.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with no support but your printer may vary, also since its tall and thin a brim or raft is probably a good idea.

title: Threaded 8mm Inductive Sensor Mount for 5015 Fan (Anet A8 bed leveling)

description.text:
I made this specifically for my setup which already has some stuff bolted to the fan but it should mount to just about any 5015 nozzle cooling fan provided there's space available.

The threading is 18mmx1mm which should fit most 8mm inductive sensors (this is mine http://amzn.to/2GbXWjn) it just tight enough that you shouldn't require any lock nuts on the sensor to keep it in place, which makes setting z-offset a breeze since you can just home the machine and threads the sensor in progressively a few time to dial it in rather than messing with the firmware z offsets etc.

video of it in action : https://www.instagram.com/p/BgDkcqRF71d/?taken-by=tableft_workshop

I used bilinear leveling in Marlin 1.1.x and on my Anet A8 the offsets & boundaries were:
//these were just approximations but they worked,
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 37 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -55 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 180
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 160

author: TabLeft

title: Flipping Minimalist wallet for 6 cards
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Created a slim/minimalist flipping wallet for 6 cards. I highly recommend inserting 6 cards if you use it (cards will hold in place even if you turn the wallet around). There is a possibility to insert some cash (coins or bills).

What you need:
4xM2 12mm (i use machine screws but normal screws will work too)

Instruction:
If your printer has soluble support material, do not follow the instructions above and just print horizontally.
Otherwise:
-Print left and right parts vertically (brim highly recommended)
-Remove the supports where the links will be
-Print 2 "links"
-Tricky parts: You will have to remove the support inside the screw column (Yes, the hole from the bottom and top screw is the same, thats why the lenght of the screw you will use does not matter). To remove the support, fit the m2 screw inside the holes and screw until you see the support's plastic coming out from the opposite side of the column. So if you are pushing in the bottom screw you will see plastic coming out of the top hole.
-Screw the 2 links so that the wallet can flip

Printed on a Anet A8
30mm/s speed
0.2mm height
0.4mm width

Highly recommand a brim (10mm+) even tho I have been able to print them only using a skirt. (Failed multiple times as it would fall on the last layers)

Make sure that it only does a support for 85 degrees+, otherwise it will create a support for the center circle.

I would really be happy to see somebody make it with a good printer! (Mine has many issues)

Anet A8

No

Yes

description.text:
This is just a simple adapter, to mount an BLTOUCH sensor onto any E3D hotend mount, that is holding the hotend on the upper part of the E3D Hotend.

Of course, this is not useful for anyone who wants to to keep their BLTOUCH mounted permanently, but on my Delta, I only need to do the normal calibration routine (G32) and the grid leveling (G31 on smoothieware) once and than I can remove my BLTOUCH and install my hotend.
With this mounting method, there is no X/Y offset between the BLTOUCH probe and the nozzle, which will give me the best calibration results (I have no piezo system).

Great for Christmas or any other occasions that might also be called Christmas.

title: Dice Tray and Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This should be a fairly simple dice tray and holder to print for most printers which are large enough to print it. The outer edges of the dice tray measure 15.4 cm x 21.4 cm x 5 cm. The built in dice holder should be capable of holding 8 standard sized dice (d4-d20). The points at both ends of the dice holder are sized appropriately to hold 5 mm x 1 mm magnets to keep the lid in place, with a small allotment for printer tolerance. The sides of the lid were also sized down to provide a decent tolerance, just in case.

Please share any prints that you have done and share any comments or improvements that you may have. You are free to use this or build upon this build, future improvements do include a lid for the dice tray. Enjoy!

-Sean

EDIT (3/8/2018): fixed the magnet receivers for the lid, one had previously been drawn too deep and they are now at the same depth.

EDIT (3/9/2018): I finally printed the first prototype, setting everything so that my printer could print as fast as possible the base printed without a problem. The lid also printed without a problem, I have uploaded a new .STL with beveled edges on the lid. I noticed when taking the lid out of the base it could sometimes be difficult with dice in the tray, so I'm hoping that this helps with that. I'm printing a new lid now and will upload pictures for everyone later this afternoon. Thank you

EDIT #2 (3/9/2018): Increased size of receptors for magnets to make it easier for insertion of magnets. Original was a bit of a tight fit, they should fit much easier though. If anyone has any problems I can increase the tolerance in future versions.

This is the ultimate cubic fractal, each face will be completely covered with child cubes of all the following recursion levels.
This was tough to figure out as I am not used to the declarative programming style used by OpenSCAD, but eventually it worked.
The fractal will get a whole lot more complex with each additional recursion step and takes ages to render(quite literally if you overdo it...).
In mathematical terms this is the quadratic Koch curve extended in the third dimension: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koch_snowflake

title: AxiomClamp - Simple Action Cam Board Clamp

description.text:
I saw a simple clamp on Thingiverse the other day and felt inspired to model this somewhat similar AxiomClamp in order to mount common action cameras to boards or tables.

The AxiomClamp works best together with the OxionCam mount (attached) to rotate the camera on the Y-axis by 90º and add the ability to tilt the camera around the X-axis. In this example the action camera mount is my SQ11mount for the Quelima SQ11.

AxiomClamp and OxionCam together allow to tilt the mounted by 180º on the X-axis and the same on the Y-axis, depending on the dimensions of the camera of course.

Use the 16 mm version for thin boards and the 20 mm version for 20+ mm boards. Let me know if you need a clamp for much larger boards because it's fairly easy to add some length.

I might add an STL for a working M5x22 or M5x23 screw in the future.

This spool holder is made to hold a spool of filament on the CENTER of the top rail of the Tevo Tornado frame. My first version of this hung the spool holder over the side, and a few people expressed concern with it causing the printer to be off "balance".

I printed HUNDREDS of hours with the side spool hanger with no problems, however I thought I'd try to make something that was positioned directly in the center, if anything it would only help to even out the weight distribution, AND... it looks better! (Win/win!)

There are two "guides" included in the downloadable files that need to be used because the filament comes directly down to the extruder, causing it to go into the extruder at a rather sharp angle. The guides help to relieve the pressure/tension.

The bottom guide is very important! If you don't use it the filament will wear away at the spring loaded extruder feeder eyelet and slowly cut into it!

The guides make are very important, be sure to use them!

I'd like to redesign the bottom guide, I've played with it putting in a rod that spins to relieve the pressure (as the filament is pulled into the exturder) even more. But I've been using this one, which is 100& made on the 3d printer and it's been GREAT!

You may need to use a small file to smooth out the edges of the part that goes over the rail. I've found that depending on how the first layer is printed, if it spreads out a bit, the piece won't slide onto the railing without a little filing! To check the fit, you can turn it around and put it on backwards, they slide on smoothly with no problem "backwards". Again, if this is the case a small file or exacto place can make the other side fit and slide on easily.

title: Single Roll Filament Drybox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://youtu.be/YriatQOJfEI

Parts Needed
(purchased parts through Amazon are affiliate links)

(1) 4 inch 5/16 bolt (or 8mm threaded rod) (bought from hardware store)
(2) 5/16 nuts (or 8mm nuts for threaded rod) (bought from hardware store)
(1) PFTE Tube Cap (download in files)
(2) Rod End Holders (download in files)
(2) 8mm x 22mm x 7mm Bearings - http://amzn.to/2G9QKUU
(2) Spool Plugs - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2773587
(1) Cereal Dry Box - http://amzn.to/2toGOnq
(1) PC4 M6 PFTE fitting - http://amzn.to/2oZLieN
(1) O-ring if your fitting does not come with one. (bought from hardware store)
(1) Cup of Orange Indicating Silica Gel Beads Desiccant - http://amzn.to/2oUmdCL
(#) Any length you prefer of 4mm od/2mm id PFTE tube. - http://amzn.to/2oZLieN

Step 1: Measure the bolt to the width of where you placed the Rod End Holders inside the Cereal Dry Box and cut off the head of the bolt and any extra length of the bolt.

Step 2: Measure where you want to place the Rod End Holders inside the Cereal Dry Box, you want to make sure that the spool has enough room from the top so that you can close the dry box, and far enough away from the ends so that the spools don't rub.

Step 3: Depending on what kind of glue you're using, you may need to scuff up the inside plastic so it gets a good hold. Glue the Rod End Holders inside the Cereal Dry Box. These will be used to hold the spool in place.

Step 4: Assemble the Spool with the spool plugs, bearings, threaded rod made from the bolt and 2 nuts to hold in place on the spool.

Step 5: Pour 1 cup of Orange Indicating Silica Gel Beads Desiccant into the Cereal Dry Box

Step 6: Slide the spool into the Cereal dry box, pushing the sides out a bit to place the ends of the threaded rods into the Rod End Holders that you glued inside the box.

Step 7: Decide where you want the filament to come out of the box and drill a 5.5mm hole, be sure to deburr the hole for a better seal. Add the o-ring to the PC4 M6 fitting and screw the fitting into the hole.

Step 8: Push and lock the PFTE tube into the fitting, then thread the filament end through the PFTE tube. Place PFTE Tube Cap on end of the PFTE tube

Step 9: Secure lid of the Cereal Dry Box

Conclusion

I'm still not 100% happy with this box, but at the moment it's what I came up with. My biggest complaints about any dry boxes I've seen and this one is that 1) there isn't a way to re-roll the filament without opening the drybox (introducing more humidity) 2) there isn't a way to put the filament back through the tube when you go to use it again without opening the dry box... (again introducing more humidity).

I'm trying to come up with a way to have the rod that holds the spool come out one side with a crank on it, but there are numerous obstacles I haven't come up with solutions that I'm happy with yet.

KICKSTARTER ALERT!

We're currently running a Kickstarter campaign for the extended range of our ScatterBlocks (quick-assembling miniature terrain), so drop on by and drop us a pledge if you want the full range. For those of you supporting us (or thinking about supporting us) on Patreon, all the rewards will go to our backers there as well (as we do with all our crowdfunding campaigns).

This miniature is one of many that will be included in our new game, Wrath & Ruin (currently in development), (as part of the "Freefolk" faction), a blend of simple miniature wargaming and physical boulder-throwing (check out the videos). We're pretty excited about this one, and would love to get others in on the play testing phase before we expand and go wider with the game. Kickstarter backers at the $25 level and Patreon supporters will get the play tester kit in March (after the current campaign wraps). You can see a full demo game we ran at a local game store here.

The Wodeknight, like all the miniatures we're designing for this game, prints without the need of support material. We printed ours without a raft and at a .1 layer height with 10% infill. Also, this model will go great with the stackable/magnetized trees that will be in the next stretch goal.

Enjoy!

remixed_from.title: XYZ Da Vinci Pro Bed Plate and Spring Tensioners

title: xyz pro bed plate and spring tensioners

description.text:
Have drawn inspiration from the source file but started from scratch,

tried some other tensioners that only fit on the top but fitted poorly, needed a lot of finishing and did not like the excessive tension on the springs. I tried to modify some but had no luck in keeping that design, having it print on its back and incorperating less tension that I desired.

i have now achieved all that with this design.

re designed item, now has profiled edges for easier adjustment to make fit perfectly, minor size adjustments to spring plate for cleaner fit and incorperated more of a bushing under the screw.

holes are tight for screw fitting, I drilled to 3mm for minimal play. Some light sanding may be required to under-plate for perect fit

description.text:
Water heaters in garages are often required to have a bollard (pipe filled with concrete) to protect from errant parking jobs. The one in my garage is 3.5 in wide and right next to where we keep our shoes. I have nightmares about accidentally hitting my head on that thing which is 100% unforgiving. This calls for a soft filament print! The result is a cushiony cap! I printed it with red TPU with infill of 10% and it is nice and soft.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fKUp6czVN7A

If your bollard is 4 in, simply scale to 114.28% (4/3.5!)

print_settings.Notes:: You don't necessarily need supports, but it will cut down on the sanding you need to do after it prints.

description.text:
I wanted to turn Sneakypoo's Labyrinth Gift Box into a gambling/party game for the fundraising event we were hosting. The dimensions were changed to fit gift cards to local shops. Instead of using a plastic notch, since there was going to be heavy use of the item, I instead made it so you can screw in a 4mm machine screw that lets you reset the puzzle quickly.

I've printed this in both ABS and Taulman's Nylon Bridge material. Both turned out great and with some sanding work great.

NEED:
1 x 4mm Screw

The Game:
Solve the puzzle, get the mystery prize.

The bid. You slide your bet inside the box and get 1 minute for every increment you bid. You may not "add" to your bid after you start. - We did $1 increments. So $1 = 1 minute to try and solve the puzzle.

Adjust increments based off value of prize.

Bibo3D

Meshmixer

This is part of a group of things I am creating for my CR10S. It should work on just about anything though.

I like how the time-lapses look when the camera moves with the bed, but I needed something a bit more sturdy. Also I was aggravated by the floppy ribbon cable so I made a channel through the middle with gentle slopes at each end. You can just push it through easily.

Like I said I wanted it real sturdy so I drilled a hole in the aluminum plate that carries the build plate. You could easily make a different base if that doesn't suit you.

I made the hole in the front the right size to thread in inexpensive wide angle lenses made for phones. Turns out it's far enough away that they aren't necessary and I chose to keep the weight down to help with shaking. I might redesign the camera case front later.

I used two arms, but more could be used, they are modular like that.
